s.text: But that also means that when confronted with the choice between doing a little extra digging and writing his way around a problem, he chooses the latter every time.
The thing that struck me particularly in this regard was Healtheon's IPO.
Lewis has a lot of fun showing how fuzzy the concept is at the beginning, but by the end of the book, Healtheon is an actual company with an actual product that does ...
Lewis has a lot of fun showing how fuzzy the concept is at the beginning, but by the end of the book, Healtheon is an actual company with an actual product that does ...

And what he has done right is something big and important: He has absolutely captured what Silicon Valley is like at this moment in history--how crazy it is, how the old rules have been turned upside down, how it is filled with the sense that anything is possible, and that everyone will soon be rich, if they aren't already.
) For this, Clark reaps billions once the IPO takes place (as it inevitably does), and gets to be viewed as great Silicon Valley visionary.
